messages: 171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:33): hsivonen: What do you mean "deeper in the spec land"?  I'm still definitely an author; I just also get to write specs that I hope to be able to use in the future.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:35): 171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39: I think that disqualifies you from being "just" an author
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:36): If you are also a spec author and a browser developer
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:36): Sure, I'm not "just", but that doesn't make me "not".
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:38): No but it does make your opinion less relevant on questions aimed discerning what the average author would find intuitive
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:39): My opinion as an "average" author was compromised long ago, when I started caring about standards.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:41): Hmm.  I wonder how using <details> for a tablist would work, if you ripped out the <summary>s via CSS to display together.  Sounds like it has potential.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:48): I forget - does [open] on details reflect the current open state?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:48): yes
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:49): that might also cause mutating on parsing given a preference to open all <details> by default
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:49): and maybe when printing
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:49): Yeah, sure.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:49): I don't like it at all for that reason
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:49): That's what you want, in terms of styling, though.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:50): for styling we could just have :open
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:50): Well, I suppose you could just introduce :open, yeah.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:50): would be more consistent too
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:50): Either way works for me.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:50): Bug Hixie on it, then.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:50): why do I need to use :checked here and [open] there? aaah
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:50): Yeah, good argument.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:50): I failed to convince him
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:50): You actually file a bug?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:50): and I don't care enough I guess; I just think it's silly
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:51): no
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:51): k, I'll do so.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:51): good luck, you got my vote
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:51): How would it be reflected, then?  defaultOpen, like muted and value?
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:51): How does checked reflect?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:52): .checked is the actual value, .defaultChecked is checked="" and [checked]
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:52): Okay, cool.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:56): yeah: http://enterprise-html.com/4
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (18:56): Aw yeah.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:58): only 39 bugs left
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:58): way to go Hixie
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (18:58): Wait what
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (18:58): It has unpaired quotes
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (19:00): Also, what has science done: http://enterprise-html.com/10
